properties.text: [color=black]Corn. Grows fast, grows tall. You can harvest the ears of corn without harvesting the rest of the plant. The ears will grow back.
[color=black]Collecting Food

[color=black]Welcome to the world. First thing is first: you need to survive. For that, you'll need food and shelter.

Look around. Depending on where you are, you'll find plants on the ground that contain edibles.
[b][color=black]Acquiring Hardware

[color=black]You cannot chop down a tree without an axe. Well, you can, but you will not get any logs by punching a tree. In order to harvest wood, you're going to need a flint hatchet. You can find flint the usual way, by digging gravel, but you can also get flint when digging dirt or sand. I recommend sand if gravel isn't available, as digging dirt has some inherent danger until you have a shovel.
[b][color=black]Flaked Flint
[color=black]You can get plant fiber from grass, either digging up grassy dirt blocks or by cutting the grass on top. Simply craft the plant fiber into twine; three fiber gives one twine.

[color=black]The flint hatchet requires you to flake the flint. This is done by punching the gravel against a hard block, like stone. Just punch once, then wait a half-second before trying again. You'll hear a distinct sound when it is done correctly. It may not succeed the first time, so if you fail, just try again. Sometimes, you do destroy the flint with nothing to show for it.
[b][color=black]Plant Twine
[color=black]Index (click on text)
By: The Wanderlust Team
[color=black]Ore Processing
[b][color=black]Sticks

[color=black]The last thing you need are sticks. You can't chop down a tree yet, so you cannot get sticks the traditional way. Instead, you'll have to break a tree's leaves. They'll frequently give you sticks. Once you acquire a stick, the chipped flint, twine, and stick can be combined to make a hatchet. Now you'll be able to chop down those trees.
[b][color=black]The Crafting Table
[color=black]Once you have wood, you'll be able to make yourself a crafting table. A slightly cheaper crafting table is made using the hatchet on the log in a crafting grid.

[color=black]Due to a reduced return on planks when crafting without a saw, the normal crafting table will require two logs. Once you have a crafting table, you can make tools such as the flint saw, which gives you 3 planks, as well as a flint axe, work blade, and other such flint tools. One thing to note about flint tools: they can be repaired in the crafting grid; no anvil required! Furthermore, when you do repair them in your crafting grid, they'll retain any enchantments that have been placed on them.
[b][color=black]Flint Pickaxe
[color=black]You'll need this to collect stone and ore.

[color=black]Like other flint tools, this can be easily repaired in the crafting grid, and retains any enchantments placed on it when one does so.

Otherwise, the flint pickaxe is very similar to the stone pickaxe that we're more familiar with.
[color=black]Work Blade
[color=black]You'll need a work blade for a variety of uses.

[color=black]You can use the flint work blade to strip logs, getting them ready to split for making log piles. The bark can be used to make tannin, which is useful for curing raw hides.

Furthermore, work blades make decent makeshift weapons.
[color=black]Mud:
[color=black]Earthwax is found in moist biomes.
[color=black]Terra Clay:
[color=black]Tip: use nature's compass to find a specific biome!
[color=black]Terra clay is found in plains and near rivers.
[color=black]Silty dirt is extremely common in the following biomes: cherry blossom grove, lavender fields, prairie, snowy forest, and tundra.
[color=black]Silty Dirt:
[color=black]Earthwax:
[color=black]Ash:
[color=black]Ash can be made by putting torches in enclosed areas. The torch will create a cloud that eventually settles into a pile of ash, which can be then picked up.
[color=black]Mud can be made by mixing water with dirt. Easy? If you don't want to do it in the crafting table, you can also dig up watered farmland for mud.
[color=black]Finding Ores

[color=black]Copper Ore

Copper is one of the most common ores you can find. You'll find it in several different types of distribution: layered veins with moderately sized motherlodes and long branches; rare, but massive clouds of copper with hints of the cloud near the surface; and small clusters.

[color=black]A copper "cloud" after having the stone stripped away. Note how sparse the ore is spaced.
There is a lot of ore here!
[color=black]The first ores you'll want to find are copper, zinc, or tin. These are all fairly common ores in the Overworld.
[color=black]A copper cluster; commonly found anywhere.

[color=black]Iron Ore
Iron can be found in several different forms. It is likely the single most common material you can find in the overworld. Iron is found as goethite, limonite, hematite, magnetite, taconite, siderite, bog iron, and banded iron.

Hematite and magnetite are the most rich iron ores. They're mostly found in the deepest reaches of the earth. However, magnetite is found near the surface in beaches and deserts while hematite is found near the surface in cold regions.

Goethite, Limonite, and Taconite are found almost anywhere.
[color=black]It is likely little surprise that bog iron is found mostly in swamps. Banded iron is mostly found in plains-like biomes.

[color=black]Lead and Silver Ore
These two ores are almost never found far apart from one another. These ores tend to favor a region about 22 meters above bedrock, though it can also be found in mountains about 70 meters above sea level.

[color=black]Aluminum Ore
Also called Bauxite, this ore is most common at sea level. It can also be found in mountains about 60 meters above sea level.

[color=black]Nickel Ore
Nickel can be found about 16 meters above bedrock. It can also be found in mountains about 120 meters above sea level.

[color=black]Uranium Ore
This radioactive material is incredibly rare, unless you're in wastelands. It will generally be found 16 meters above bedrock.
As a side note, you'll likely have more luck finding uranium underneath lava pools in the Nether.

[color=black]Titanium Ore
Also called rutile, this ore can be found anywhere, but favors oceans. Outside of an ocean, it can be found about 14 meters below sea level. In oceans, it will likely be close to the bottom of the ocean.

[color=black]Tin Ore

Tin is less frequent than copper. In general, you can find it as a moderately sized motherlode with long branches. The motherlodes seem to average around 16 meters below sea level. Tin can also be found in giant clouds of ore.

[color=black]Zinc Ore

Much like tin ore, zinc spawns in motherlodes found about 16 meters below sea level. Zinc also rarely can be found in giant clouds of ore.

[color=black]Additional Note:
Sometimes, zombies can be found carrying copper, tin, and zinc ingots. Exterminating zombies may sometimes reveal these ingots.

[color=black]If you happen to be making salt in a cold biome, there are a few things you can do. One, you can change the biome. The easiest way to do this is using the Environmental Accumulators found in Dark Temples throughout the world. If you find an Environmental Accumulator in a warm biome, toss a Biome Essence Bottle in the beam, and it will absorb the biome. Carry the biome essence back home and use it where your evaporation tanks are to convert the biome.

Alternatively, put glass over the evaporation tanks. You'll have to fill them with water somehow, though. Pumping water into the tank does not reset the process.

[color=black]Salt is a bit harder to get in this world than most. You can obtain it by finding it (netjry in the overworld, fire salt in the nether, and void salt in the End), or you can make it using an evaporation tank.

If you use an evaporation tank, you have to fill it with water and leave the tank exposed to the sun. It will dry out over time (faster in hot biomes such as deserts). However, rain will reset the process. In cold biomes, the rain might be frequent enough that you'll never get any salt.

[color=black]When exploring, you'll sometimes find a box of eternal closure filled with a named vengeance spirit. These "forgotten players" have random drops. Some are useful, some are worthless. To find out what they drop, you need a device called a "Spirit Furnace."

You might recognize the player's names. They include popular YouTubers, mod developers, and modpack developers. Those of us on the Wanderlust Renewed team have added a few of our own, as well.

[color=black]Once the evaporation tank is full of salt, you can remove it using a shovel. However, the raw salt can be moved to the seasoning rack using a hopper or any other method of item transportation.

You cannot use raw salt (it is poisonous), so you're going to need a salt seasoning rack to make salt.
[b][color=black]Flint Saw
[color=black]Getting only 2 planks per log means chopping more trees. The flint saw makes things a little bit better.
[color=black]When using the flint saw to cut logs into planks, you get 3 planks per log. Copper, iron, emerald, and diamond saws will all give 4 planks per log.
[color=black]Stone Gallagher
[color=black]This is a useful tool for smashing things, often allowing you to get back the component parts, such as quartz from a quartz block.

[color=black]One of the more useful applications for the gallager is using it to turn ingots into plates early on, which you'll need to make a copper saw. Another thing you can make is limestone slack, which you'll need to make grout.

[color=black]While there are several methods of processing ore, while we're in the Stone Age, we are very limited. For the most part, you're limited to processing copper, tin, zinc, lead, and silver. The easiest method to process these may be the furnace.
[color=black]Simply place a clay ball on the drying rack and wait for a while. The drying rack does dry faster when placed under the sun.
[color=black]Processing Ores
[color=black]You're going to need a drying rack to produce dried bricks. You'll need many of the tools shown in the [i]Aquiring Hardware[/i] chapter.
[b][color=black]Lapis Ore

[color=black]Lapis ore's vertical veins are nearly identical to redstone veins. there are a few minor differences, though. Lapis veins are found about half as frequently as redstone, and the origin of the vein is slightly higher, meaning you are more likely to find it on the surface.
[b][color=black]Redstone Ore

[color=black]Redstone ore, like lapis ore, is found in tall vertical veins. These veins usually originate near bedrock and can extend almost all the way up to the surface. This means that you can find bits of lapis and redstone on the surface, and when you do, it is a hint that there is more ore underneath.

The vertical veins encourage you to dig down. Never dig straight down.
